data.description: State appropriation from the Accountability Court Fund to the AOC for FY 2026. Act 776 appropriates $400,000 from the Accountability Court Fund for operating expenses and grants/aid to adult and juvenile specialty courts.  The Accountability Court Fund is a trust fund created by Ark. Code §19‑5‑1144 consisting of grants and other funds and is used by the AOC for specialty courts.

data.destination: Arkansas Medicaid (DHS) – Peer Support Routing
data.statutory_basis:
CMS’s July 22 2025 approval letter for the Arkansas “Opportunities to Test Transition‑Related Strategies to Support
Community Reentry from Institutions for Mental Disease” Section 1115(a) demonstration requires the state to engage
peer support specialists to help beneficiaries make connections with community‑based providers and to implement
strategies such as having peer support specialists in emergency departments to assist with discharge and referral to
treatment providers【29633513042789†L1460-L1494】.  This demonstration focuses on improving transitions for
individuals with serious mental illness or substance use disorder, but the approval letter does not specify a
dedicated funding amount, so the amount is left unspecified.

data.source: Substance Use Prevention, Treatment & Recovery Services Block Grant (SAMHSA SUBG)
data.destination: Arkansas Department of Human Services – Substance Abuse Program
data.statutory_basis:
The Arkansas Department of Human Services describes the Substance Abuse Block Grant (SABG), also called the
Substance Use Prevention, Treatment and Recovery Services Block Grant (SUBG), as providing funds to plan,
implement and evaluate activities that prevent and treat substance abuse.  SAMHSA requires grantees to spend no

【694662080385875†L862-L870】.  The site does not publish the FY‑2025/2026 award amount, so the amount is left
unspecified in this artifact.

data.description: Defines a ‘specialty court program’ to include drug courts, DWI/BWI courts, mental‑health courts, veterans treatment courts, juvenile drug courts, HOPE courts and other Supreme‑Court‑approved programs.  Requires that programs be included in the judicial circuit’s administrative plan under Administrative Orders 14 and 18 and be approved by the Supreme Court.  Establishes the Specialty Court Program Advisory Committee and mandates regular evaluation of programs.

Authorizes mental‑health specialty courts.  These courts offer judicial monitoring of intensive mental‑health treatment and enforce strict supervision.  Creation of a mental‑health court requires approval through the judicial circuit’s administrative plan; the program must incorporate treatment integration, non‑adversarial approach, early risk assessment, coordinated strategies among court and providers, and frequent drug testing.

data.effects: Section 27 of Act 776 (2025) appropriates federal funds to the Administrative Office of the Courts for drug court enhancement.  It allocates more than $9 million for FY 2026, covering operating expenses, travel and training, professional fees, grants and aid, and an adult treatment court program【556692708300381†L661-L679】.  This appropriation ensures the AOC has resources to support adult and juvenile specialty courts through the Drug Court Enhancement program.

Arkansas Code § 16‑90‑717 creates the Crime Victims Reparations Revolving Fund.  The statute provides that a continuing fund is established in the State Treasury for the Crime Victims Reparations Board.  All moneys received from any source and all interest earned remain in the fund.  The Board may budget and expend the moneys to implement the crime‑victim reparations program and the sexual‑assault statutes【759199032674464†L72-L83】.

Section 19‑5‑1144 establishes the Accountability Court Fund on the books of the State Treasurer, Auditor of State and Chief Fiscal Officer.  The fund consists of grants or other funds received.  It is to be used by the Administrative Office of the Courts for adult and juvenile specialty court programs according to a formula developed by the Arkansas Judicial Council and approved by the Legislative Council【5346883730037†L70-L83】.  The fund provides dedicated support for specialty courts such as drug courts and veterans courts.

data.description: Creates the Accountability Court Fund as a trust fund on the state’s books.  The fund consists of grants and other funds and is used by the AOC for adult and juvenile specialty court programs based on a formula developed by the Judicial Council, reviewed by the Specialty Court Program Advisory Committee and approved by the Legislative Council.

data.effects: The Court Technology Improvement Act of 2009 (HB 1353, enacted as Act 328) authorizes the Arkansas Supreme Court, through the Administrative Office of the Courts, to design, purchase, implement and operate a comprehensive automated court management system.  The Act makes the system self‑supporting by requiring that all funding be generated through use of the system rather than general revenue and is known as the "Court Technology Improvement Act of 2009"【877678106644158†L67-L118】.  It amends statutes governing credit‑card payments and collection of fines to enable electronic payments and supports a fee structure that funds court technology improvements【877678106644158†L67-L118】.

data.citation: Ark. Code Ann. § 19‑5‑302 (Department of Community Correction Fund Account)
data.effects: In the State General Government Fund account statute, § 19‑5‑302(12) creates the Department of Community Correction Fund Account.  The account consists of general revenues and non‑revenue income derived from probation, parole and community correction program services, along with other funds provided by law.  Moneys in the account are to be used for the maintenance, operation and improvement of the Department of Community Correction【134496210289864†L278-L290】.  This fund supports community‑based corrections and probation services.

Section 19‑5‑306 establishes the Department of Human Services Fund and its various fund accounts.  For example, the Behavioral Health Services Fund Account within this section is used for the maintenance and operation of the Division of Aging, Adult, and Behavioral Health Services.  The account consists of general revenues, nonrevenue income derived from services, federal reimbursement funds, paying patient fees, and matching funds【645878655316602†L70-L94】.  The provision ensures that DHS has a dedicated fund structure to support behavioral health and other human‑services programs.

data.effects: Act 58 of 2021 amends Ark. Code § 16‑10‑139 to define "specialty court program" to include pre‑adjudication programs, drug courts, Swift and Certain Accountability programs, and veterans treatment or DWI specialty courts.  It directs the Specialty Court Program Advisory Committee to evaluate programs using nationally recognized standards, ensure resources are directed to high‑risk, high‑need offenders, require evidence‑based practices, and ensure that specialty courts address substance dependency and mental‑health issues among participants【30507785040088†L39-L104】.  The Act expands authority for DHS and the courts to operate specialty court programs that prioritize treatment for substance use disorders.

Act 776 of 2025 is an appropriation act for the Administrative Office of the Courts for FY 2026.  In addition to general operating appropriations, specific sections provide funding for drug court enhancement, accountability court programs, adult drug‑court expenses and specialty courts【556692708300381†L661-L679】【556692708300381†L739-L776】.  These appropriations ensure that the AOC has resources for court operations, specialty court programs, and associated support services.

data.citation: Drug Utilization Review (DUR) Board Bylaws (revised July 2025)
data.administering_body: Arkansas Medicaid – Drug Utilization Review Board
data.effects: The July 2025 bylaws of the Arkansas Drug Utilization Review Board explain that the board is established under 42 U.S.C. § 1396r‑8(g)(3) and 42 C.F.R. § 456.716.  The board’s mission is to ensure safe, effective and clinically‑sound pharmaceutical care for Medicaid beneficiaries.  Membership includes physicians, pharmacists and other professionals appointed by the governor, and members must be free of conflicts of interest.  The bylaws require the board to review clinical evidence, develop drug‑use criteria, monitor patterns of utilization and make recommendations to the Division of Medical Services to improve patient outcomes【674902515603826†L11-L40】【674902515603826†L52-L85】.  These policies govern how the board reviews medications and manages formularies.

data.effects: In July 2021, Governor Asa Hutchinson, Attorney General Leslie Rutledge, Association of Arkansas Counties Executive Director Chris Villines and Arkansas Municipal League Director Mark Hayes signed the Arkansas Opioids Memorandum of Understanding.  The MOU provides that the state, counties and cities will equally share Arkansas’s opioid settlement funds and directs that the money be used for evidence‑based strategies to abate the opioid epidemic【332936500398358†L144-L148】.  The MOU establishes funding allocations and joint administration through the Arkansas Opioid Recovery Partnership.

data.effects: Paula Stone serves as Director of OSAMH. She oversees the state’s public mental health system, the state’s forensic system, federal grant programs aimed at preventing and treating substance use disorder, and the team that leads the Arkansas State Hospital【517013002479678†L877-L889】.

data.citation: ARORP article: Governor of Arkansas elects new Drug Director (Feb. 17, 2023)
data.effects: On February 17, 2023 Governor Sarah Huckabee Sanders announced that Thomas Fisher, a former Department of Justice and DEA official, would serve as Arkansas’s new Drug Director. Fisher will succeed Boyce Hamlet and oversee the state’s drug policies while continuing collaboration with former Drug Director Kirk Lane【883227464789966†L75-L87】.

data.citation: News release: Arkansas Drug Director changing job (July 27, 2022)
data.effects: Kirk Lane served as Arkansas Drug Director from 2017 until August 2022. Appointed by Governor Asa Hutchinson, he coordinated statewide efforts to prevent substance abuse, launched the Arkansas Naloxone Program and led peer recovery initiatives. His resignation announcement noted that he had been at the forefront of overdose prevention and peer recovery programs【23235813013277†L853-L889】.

data.effects: The Provider Enrollment Unit manages enrollment for Arkansas Medicaid providers. Providers must report National Provider Identifier numbers and re‑enroll every five years【273577708421788†L998-L1053】.

data.effects: Section 41 of the 2015 Criminal Justice Reform Act (SB 472) creates the Accountability Court Fund as a trust fund consisting of grants or other funds.  The fund is used by the Department of Community Correction to support specialty court programs as defined by § 16‑10‑139【407800006528432†L3261-L3283】.  Subsequent sections of the Act amend Title 19 and Title 16 to create the Specialty Court Program Fund and require that user fees collected from specialty‑court participants be used for treatment services, program evaluation and crisis intervention for specialty court programs【407800006528432†L3292-L3419】.  The Act establishes accountability and funding mechanisms for specialty courts statewide.

data.description: Administrative Order 14 (as amended) governs the administration of circuit courts.  It recognizes specialty courts as special dockets within circuit courts and requires that any specialty program be described in the circuit’s administrative plan and approved by the Supreme Court before implementation.  District court plans must be appended to the circuit plan and approved by the Supreme Court.

data.claim_summary: Arkansas Code §10‑3‑2901 establishes the Specialty Court Program Advisory Committee, listing members including the Chief Justice, AOC director, judges, and state officials; the committee promotes collaboration and develops recommendations for adult and juvenile specialty courts【479071177763276†L69-L123】.

data.claim_summary: Ark. Code § 10-3-2901 establishes the Specialty Court Program Advisory Committee, listing members such as the Chief Justice, Director of the Administrative Office of the Courts, circuit and district judges, juvenile drug court judge, directors of Community Correction and Human Services, a prosecutor, public defender, legislators, and the Arkansas Drug Director; the committee promotes collaboration on adult and juvenile specialty courts and designs evaluations as required by § 16-10-139【479071177763276†L69-L123】.

source.title: Arkansas Code §10-3-2901 - Specialty Court Program Advisory Committee

data.claim_summary: Arkansas Code §16‑10‑139 defines specialty court programs to include DWI courts, mental health courts, veterans courts, juvenile drug courts and HOPE courts; it requires that the Specialty Court Program Advisory Committee evaluate programs and that the Supreme Court approve specialty courts【470432877689858†L74-L121】.

source.title: Arkansas Code §16‑10‑139 – Specialty court program evaluation and approval

data.claim_summary: Ark. Code § 16-10-139 defines 'specialty court program' to include pre-adjudication programs, drug courts, DWI/BWI courts, mental health courts, veterans treatment courts, juvenile drug courts, HOPE courts and domestic violence courts; it requires that specialty court programs operated by circuit or district courts be approved by the Supreme Court and evaluated by the Specialty Court Program Advisory Committee using nationally recognized standards and a uniform evaluation process【482478614226997†L74-L110】.

source.title: Arkansas Code §16-10-139 - Specialty court program evaluation and approval

data.claim_summary: Arkansas Code §16‑98‑303 authorizes each judicial district to establish drug court programs and allows juvenile drug court programs in delinquency or family‑in‑need‑of‑services cases; it states that services cannot be ordered unless appropriation and funding are available【390323063622848†L73-L98】【390323063622848†L100-L127】.

source.title: Arkansas Code §16‑98‑303 – Drug court programs authorized

data.claim_summary: Ark. Code § 16-98-303 authorizes each judicial district to establish a drug court program and allows juvenile drug court programs in delinquency, family, and dependency-neglect cases; it states that judges may not order services unless appropriations, funding, and positions are available and directs the Division of Community Correction to provide positions, treatment and services for high-risk offenders【759532697388275†L73-L118】.

source.title: Arkansas Code §16-98-303 - Drug court programs authorized

data.claim_summary: Arkansas Code §16‑98‑304 provides that adult or juvenile drug court judges may order offenders to pay court costs, treatment costs, supervision fees, and local program fees; fees are credited to the county administration of justice fund or local drug court program fund【912600219781708†L73-L108】.

source.title: Arkansas Code §16‑98‑304 – Costs and fees

data.claim_summary: Ark. Code § 16-98-304 provides that a drug court judge may order offenders to pay court costs, treatment costs, drug testing costs, local program user fees, supervision fees, and monitoring fees. The statute requires the judge to establish payment schedules, directs that court costs and program user fees be remitted to the court clerk for transfer to the county treasury, credits local program user fees to a local drug court program fund, and directs specified fees to the Department of Community Correction【5886943749931†L73-L110】.

source.title: Arkansas Code §16-98-304 - Cost and fees

data.claim_summary: Ark. Code § 16-98-305 requires the Department of Community Correction to provide drug counselor, probation officer, administrative assistant positions, drug testing, and intensive treatment services for adult drug court programs based on a formula developed by the Administrative Office of the Courts and reviewed by the Specialty Court Program Advisory Committee. The statute also requires the Department of Human Services to provide similar resources for juvenile cases and directs the Administrative Office of the Courts to provide funding and support for local drug court operations and assist the advisory committee【962587248890004†L93-L141】.

source.title: Arkansas Code §16-98-305 - Required resources

data.description: An addendum to the Second Judicial District administrative plan explains that the Veterans Diversion Program was implemented in 2015 through SAMHSA’s Adult Treatment Court Collaborative funding.  Local partners collaborated to address veterans’ needs.  The program also secured a Bureau of Justice Assistance grant to enhance services and operates a voluntary pre‑conviction, post‑plea program with intensive supervision and mandatory treatment.
data.source: Addendum to the 2020 Plan of the Second Judicial District (Veterans Diversion Program)
data.quote: Through funding from the Substance Abuse and Mental Health Services Administration's (SAMHSA) Adult Treatment Court Collaborative Funding, the Arkansas Second Judicial District Veterans Diversion Program was implemented in 2015 ... funding was recently obtained through the Bureau of Justice Assistance's Adult Drug Court Discretionary Funding to enhance the services provided by the court 【581215623174875†L8-L33】

data.claim_summary: A November 14, 2024 news release from the Arkansas Attorney General announces a grant of up to $1 million from the state's opioid settlement funds to the Arkansas Specialty Courts Program. The grant will provide funding for supportive and restorative services such as transitional housing, mental health treatment, peer recovery support, and transportation assistance【714061558245142†L270-L324】.

source.title: Attorney General Griffin Announces Grant from State Opioid Settlement Funds to Arkansas Specialty Courts Program

data.description: A news release from the Arkansas Rural Health Partnership (ARHP) announces a five‑year, $2 million grant from SAMHSA to expand peer recovery support services in collaboration with adult treatment drug courts.  The grant provides training and resources, offers job assistance, housing and transportation support, reduces stigma and builds support groups.  Judges note that peer recovery specialists bring valuable lived experience and the grant will sustain and expand peer support in court settings.
data.source: Arkansas Rural Health Partnership news release (Nov 18 2024)
data.quote: The Arkansas Rural Health Partnership's new five‑year, $2M project ... offers training and resources ... providing transportation for healthcare appointments and advocating for better local infrastructure ... Peer Recovery Specialists bring invaluable lived experience and understanding to the courtroom ... this five-year grant is a significant step towards establishing a sustainable and impactful program 【165071006859232†L47-L90】

data.claim_summary: The Arkansas Budget and Appropriation Process document notes that the General Assembly convenes in fiscal session at noon on the second Monday in February when the primary election is held in May and on the second Wednesday in April when the primary is in March. Joint rules require appropriation bills to be filed no later than the fifteenth day of the fiscal session, with extensions requiring a two‑thirds vote. The fiscal session may last up to thirty days and may be extended once by up to fifteen days with a three‑fourths vote of the General Assembly.

source.title: Arkansas Budget and Appropriation Process
source.issuing_body: Fiscal Services Division, Arkansas General Assembly

data.value: Arkansas specialty courts operate under the judiciary (AOC) rather than the Department of Human Services.  Programs must be included in a judicial circuit’s administrative plan and approved by the Supreme Court; they are funded through legislative appropriations (Specialty Court Program Fund and Accountability Court Fund), federal grants and local fees rather than Medicaid.
data.notes: Statutes and administrative orders show that specialty court programs are approved by the Supreme Court and overseen by the Specialty Court Program Advisory Committee.  Appropriation acts provide direct funding to the AOC, indicating that specialty courts bypass DHS/Medicaid funding streams.

data.value: Peer recovery specialists providing services in specialty courts must hold certification from a DHS‑approved accrediting entity through the Arkansas Peer Recovery Program and cannot be disqualified from Medicaid participation if their offense is non‑violent and they obtained certification after the offense.
data.notes: The Arkansas Peer Recovery Program provides a three‑tier credentialing process administered by the DHS Office of Substance Abuse and Mental Health; certification is authorized by Ark. Code §20‑64‑602(b)(19).  Ark. Code §20‑77‑135 prevents DHS from disqualifying a peer support specialist from Medicaid if certified by an accredited organization approved by the Arkansas Alcohol and Drug Abuse Coordinating Council and the offense is non‑violent.

data.field: Peer support services in specialty courts
data.value: Specialty court programs incorporate peer support into their service delivery.  Mental‑health court handbooks require participants to attend peer support meetings, and federal grants (e.g., SAMHSA grant to ARHP) fund peer recovery specialists for adult drug courts.
data.notes: The mental‑health court orientation in Benton County mandates peer support meetings, demonstrating programmatic reliance on peer support.  The ARHP grant emphasises deploying Peer Recovery Specialists within court programs, confirming that peer support services are not only allowed but actively integrated and federally funded.

evidence_basis: Section 19-12-101 states that this chapter may be cited as the Tobacco Settlement Proceeds Act【281429877317169†L72-L76】
The definitions section defines the "Arkansas Biosciences Institute Program" and its role in distributing tobacco settlement proceeds【703598692190882†L73-L92】
The definitions section defines key terms used in the Tobacco Settlement Proceeds Act, such as the Commission and various program accounts【703598692190882†L73-L92】
Section 19-12-102 defines the Arkansas Tobacco Settlement Commission Fund, which supports the commission’s operations【703598692190882†L73-L92】
Section 19-12-102 defines the "Arkansas Healthy Century Trust Fund" and references its creation under §19-12-107【703598692190882†L73-L92】
The definitions include the "Medicaid Expansion Program Account" that receives a portion of tobacco settlement funds【703598692190882†L73-L92】

Section 19-12-107 explains that investment earnings from the Arkansas Healthy Century Trust Fund may be used for responsibilities under §19‑12‑103 or health‑related programs and that the principal can be appropriated by law for health‑related purposes【501832390530729†L74-L118】

Section 19-12-107 creates the Arkansas Healthy Century Trust Fund on the books of the State Treasurer, Auditor, and Chief Fiscal Officer and places it under the administration of the State Board of Finance【501832390530729†L74-L118】
The statute states that the Arkansas Healthy Century Trust Fund is a perpetual trust with the principal to be preserved and invested; only investment earnings may be used【501832390530729†L74-L118】

The statute states that 22.8% of Tobacco Settlement Program Fund deposits are distributed to the Arkansas Biosciences Institute Program and 34.2% are distributed to the Medicaid Expansion Program account【949500341886125†L74-L116】

The statute creates the Tobacco Settlement Program Fund on the books of the Treasurer, Auditor and Chief Fiscal Officer and directs the State Board of Finance to administer it【949500341886125†L74-L116】
Section 19-12-108 provides that 15.8% of deposits in the Tobacco Settlement Program Fund go to the Targeted State Needs Program account【949500341886125†L74-L116】
The Medicaid Expansion Program expands coverage and benefits for pregnant women and adults aged 19–64 and 65 and older【377346295156413†L74-L100】
The statute provides home and community‑based services for individuals with intellectual and developmental disabilities under the Medicaid Expansion Program【377346295156413†L74-L100】
Section 19-12-116 directs the Department of Human Services to establish a Medicaid Expansion Program as part of the Arkansas Medicaid Program【377346295156413†L74-L100】
The statute lists exemptions to disclosure, such as records pertaining to incarcerated felons and other categories protected by law【628739949745494†L71-L112】
Failure to provide access to public records can result in awards of attorney’s fees and other penalties under the Freedom of Information Act【628739949745494†L71-L112】
The Arkansas Freedom of Information Act provides that all public records are open to inspection and copying by any citizen during regular business hours【628739949745494†L71-L112】
Requests for public records may be made in person, by telephone, fax, mail, or email and custodians must provide access in a reasonable time【628739949745494†L71-L112】
Custodians must respond to FOIA requests within a reasonable time and may charge the actual costs of copying the records【628739949745494†L71-L112】

evidence_basis: Opioid Treatment Programs must pay the application fee and undergo high‑risk level screening to enroll in Medicare【829416069198872†L80-L140】
The regulation requires OTPs to maintain and submit lists of physicians and pharmacists authorized to prescribe or dispense covered controlled substances【829416069198872†L80-L140】
Medicare payment for opioid treatment services requires a program to enroll as an Opioid Treatment Program (OTP) and meet Medicare enrollment requirements【829416069198872†L80-L140】
The regulation mandates that an OTP must have a current certification by SAMHSA under 42 C.F.R. §8.11; provisional certifications do not meet the requirement【829416069198872†L80-L140】
Assets of a qualified settlement fund must be physically segregated from the transferor’s assets, meaning they are not commingled with other property【147710822878547†L97-L123】
A qualified settlement fund must be established by or approved by a governmental authority and remain under the authority’s continuing jurisdiction【147710822878547†L97-L123】

The regulation requires that a qualified settlement fund be created to resolve or satisfy claims resulting from events such as torts, breaches of contract, or violations of law【147710822878547†L97-L123】
